symptoms.name: Nausea and vomiting
symptoms.description: Common due to hormonal changes (hCG, estrogen). Often called morning sickness, though it can occur anytime.
symptoms.advice: Eat small, frequent meals. Avoid spicy or fatty foods. Try ginger tea or crackers. Consult a doctor if vomiting is severe (possible hyperemesis gravidarum).
symptoms.source: ACOG, Morning Sickness: Nausea and Vomiting of Pregnancy, 2023

symptoms.name: Fatigue
symptoms.description: Caused by increased progesterone and metabolic demands.
symptoms.advice: Rest when possible. Maintain a balanced diet rich in iron and protein. Stay hydrated.

symptoms.name: Spotting
symptoms.description: Light bleeding may occur due to implantation or cervical sensitivity.
symptoms.advice: Monitor the amount and duration. Contact a healthcare provider if spotting is heavy or accompanied by pain.

symptoms.name: Severe abdominal pain
symptoms.description: May indicate ectopic pregnancy or miscarriage.

key_nutrients.purpose: Supports increased blood volume and prevents anemia.

key_nutrients.supplement: Not typically needed if diet is adequate

nutrition.source: CDC, Pregnancy Nutrition, 2024; ACOG, Nutrition During Pregnancy, 2023

exercise.recommendations: 30 minutes of moderate exercise (e.g., walking, prenatal yoga) most days.
exercise.benefits: Improves mood, reduces fatigue, prepares for labor.
exercise.avoid: High-impact sports, activities with fall risk (e.g., skiing).

mental_health.recommendations: Practice deep breathing or meditation. Join a prenatal support group if feeling anxious.
mental_health.advice: Discuss with a healthcare provider if symptoms last >2 weeks.

symptoms.name: Back pain
symptoms.description: Caused by weight gain and shifting center of gravity.
symptoms.advice: Maintain good posture. Use a supportive chair. Try prenatal yoga or gentle stretching.
symptoms.source: Mayo Clinic, Back Pain During Pregnancy, 2024

symptoms.name: Heartburn
symptoms.description: Due to hormonal changes and growing uterus pressing on stomach.
symptoms.advice: Eat small, frequent meals. Avoid spicy or acidic foods. Sleep with head elevated.

symptoms.name: Swelling (edema)
symptoms.description: Fluid retention in legs or ankles due to increased blood volume.
symptoms.advice: Elevate feet when sitting. Avoid tight clothing. Contact a doctor if swelling is sudden or severe (possible preeclampsia).

symptoms.name: Severe headache
symptoms.description: May indicate preeclampsia, especially with vision changes or upper abdominal pain.
symptoms.source: ACOG, Preeclampsia and High Blood Pressure, 2022

key_nutrients.purpose: Supports fetal brain and eye development.
Supports fetal tissue growth and maternal health.

nutrition.source: CDC, Pregnancy Nutrition, 2024; ACOG, Nutrition During Pregnancy, 2023

exercise.recommendations: Continue moderate exercise (e.g., swimming, walking). Aim for 150 minutes per week.
exercise.benefits: Reduces back pain, improves sleep, boosts energy.
exercise.avoid: Lying flat on back after 20 weeks (may compress blood vessels).

mental_health.recommendations: Engage in relaxation techniques. Discuss body image concerns with a counselor if needed.
mental_health.advice: Seek professional help for mental health concerns.

symptoms.name: Braxton Hicks contractions
symptoms.description: Irregular, painless contractions preparing for labor.
symptoms.advice: Rest and hydrate. Differentiate from true labor (regular, intensifying contractions).

symptoms.name: Shortness of breath
symptoms.description: Caused by the growing uterus pressing on the diaphragm.
symptoms.advice: Sit upright, avoid heavy exertion. Contact a doctor if severe or sudden.

symptoms.name: Heavy vaginal bleeding
symptoms.description: May indicate placental abruption or preterm labor.

symptoms.name: Decreased fetal movement
symptoms.advice: Perform a kick count (10 movements in 2 hours). Contact a healthcare provider immediately if reduced.

key_nutrients.purpose: Supports fetal bone health and maternal immunity.
Prevents constipation, common in late pregnancy.

nutrition.source: CDC, Pregnancy Nutrition, 2024; ACOG, Nutrition During Pregnancy, 2023

exercise.recommendations: Light exercise (e.g., walking, pelvic floor exercises) to maintain mobility.
exercise.benefits: Prepares for labor, reduces swelling, improves circulation.

mental_health.recommendations: Prepare for childbirth with classes or counseling. Discuss postpartum expectations.
mental_health.advice: Seek support from a mental health professional or hotline (e.g., 1-833-943-5746).

avoid_substances.risk: Preterm birth, low birth weight, SIDS

avoid_substances.advice: Avoid all recreational drugs. Seek addiction support.

medications.advice: Consult a healthcare provider before taking any medication, including over-the-counter drugs and supplements. Avoid NSAIDs (e.g., ibuprofen) unless prescribed.
